Expectation1: Adhere to professional standards and operational protocols.
Situation1: A mandatory pre-shift briefing on new operational procedures is about to start.
Expectation2: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation2: The nun has been chosen to represent the convent and lead a prayer vigil at a major public religious event.
Story: I sat in the break room, uniform crisp, cap in hand, waiting for the supervisor to begin the pre-shift briefing. The new operational procedures were crucial—missing even a detail could mean risking passenger safety or my job. My phone buzzed quietly in my pocket. A message from Mother Superior: “We need you to lead the prayer vigil tonight. The archbishop will be present. It’s an honor for our convent.” My heart pounded. The vigil was scheduled to start just as my shift began. As a nun, I was expected to be a spiritual guide, to put faith and community above all else. But as a subway operator, I was trusted to keep the city moving, to be reliable and precise. I could feel the weight of both uniforms—the habit beneath my work shirt, the cross under my ID badge. The supervisor called my name, and I felt the eyes of my colleagues and my sisters upon me, each expecting me to fulfill my duty. I closed my eyes, torn between the rails and the rosary, unsure which path to follow.
